hook.text: Microsoft borrows from you and pays more interest than the US government would. That extra yield is the risk premium.

buildup.text: Corporate bonds fund business operations. Investment-grade bonds come from strong companies like Apple or Google.

discovery.text: The spread over Treasuries reflects default risk. A 1% spread means the company pays 1% more than the government.

twist.text: In a recession, corporate spreads widen fast. Investors demand more yield as fear of default grows.

climax.text: Investment-grade corporate bonds have a historical default rate under 0.1% per year. The extra yield usually pays off.

punchline.text: Corporate bonds pay more. That premium is the price of uncertainty.

quiz.question: What does the 'spread' on a corporate bond represent?
options: The extra yield over Treasuries for default risk
The number of years to maturity
